elements.content: The photocatalytic production of syngas from CO2 and water is an attractive and straightforward way for both solar energy storage and sustainable development. Here, we combined the hybrid shell of a bimetallic metal–organic framework (MOF) Zn/Co-zeolitic imidazolate framework (ZIF) and the hybrid photoactive center of Ni-doped CdS nanoparticles (Ni@CdS) to construct a new “2 + 2” photocatalysis system Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIF through a facile self-assembly process, which exhibited a double-synergic effect for visible light harvesting and CO2 conversion, leading to one of the highest photocatalytic syngas production rates and excellent recyclability. The H2/CO of syngas ratios can be readily adjusted by controlling the ratio of Zn/Co in the hybrid MOF shell.

Here, we combined the hybrid shell of a bimetallic metal-organic framework (MOF) Zn/Co-zeolitic imidazolate framework (ZIF) and the hybrid photoactive center of Ni-doped CdS nanoparticles (Ni@CdS) to construct a new "2 + 2" photocatalysis system Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIF through a facile self-assembly process, which exhibited a double-synergic effect for visible light harvesting and CO2 conversion, leading to one of the highest photocatalytic syngas production rates and excellent recyclability. The H2/CO of syngas ratios can be readily adjusted by controlling the ratio of Zn/Co in the hybrid MOF shell.

elements.content: Excessive consumption of fossil energy has triggered a series of environmental issues and energy crises that produce excess CO2 and severely threaten the normal development of human society. Solar-driven photocatalytic conversion of CO2 and water into energetic materials such as CO, hydrogen, and fuels is one potential strategy to address these crises by storing renewable solar energy as chemical energy. Considering that the two-electron reduction of CO2 to CO is kinetically favorable compared to other multielectron reduction processes and photocatalytic water reduction to H2 easily proceeds at a relatively high rate, photocatalytic synthesis of syngas from CO2 and water becomes the reasonable strategy for both efficient chemical conversion/storage of solar energy and CO2 recycling. In addition, syngas with an adjustable molar ratio of H2/CO is an essential industrial feedstock to produce methanol, diesel, hydrocarbons, etc. However, it is still highly desirable yet challenging to design and fabricate a photocatalyst with high efficiency and selectivity for converting CO2 and water to syngas with a controllable H2/CO ratio.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Excessive consumption of fossil energy has triggered a series of environmental issues and energy crises that produce excess CO2 and severely threaten the normal development of human society. Solar-driven photocatalytic conversion of CO2 and water into energetic materials such as CO, hydrogen, and fuels is one potential strategy to address these crises by storing renewable solar energy as chemical energy. Considering that the two-electron reduction of CO2 to CO is kinetically favorable compared to other multielectron reduction processes and photocatalytic water reduction to H2 easily proceeds at a relatively high rate, photocatalytic synthesis of syngas from CO2 and water becomes the reasonable strategy for both efficient chemical conversion/storage of solar energy and CO2 recycling. In addition, syngas with an adjustable molar ratio of H2/CO is an essential industrial feedstock to produce methanol, diesel, hydrocarbons, etc. However, it is still highly desirable yet challenging to design and fabricate a photocatalyst with high efficiency and selectivity for converting CO2 and water to syngas with a controllable H2/CO ratio.

elements.content: As a typical n-type semiconductor binary sulfide, CdS has been proven as a candidate for visible-light-driven photocatalytic CO2 reduction due to the broad visible-light response, suitable band structure, and low cost. Nevertheless, the fast photogenerated electron–hole recombination kinetics of CdS limits the efficiency of the photocatalytic conversion of CO2. Doping transition metal sites can not only enhance the visible-light absorption of the catalyst but also construct surface active sites to facilitate photogenerated electrons transfer and thereby inhibit the recombination of photogenerated charges. However, the relatively low CO2 adsorption capacity and photocorrosion still hinder the application of CdS-based nanomaterials in the photocatalytic reaction.
elements.clean_text: As a typical n-type semiconductor binary sulfide, CdS has been proven as a candidate for visible-light-driven photocatalytic CO2 reduction due to the broad visible-light response, suitable band structure, and low cost. Nevertheless, the fast photogenerated electron-hole recombination kinetics of CdS limits the efficiency of the photocatalytic conversion of CO2. Doping transition metal sites can not only enhance the visible-light absorption of the catalyst but also construct surface active sites to facilitate photogenerated electrons transfer and thereby inhibit the recombination of photogenerated charges. However, the relatively low CO2 adsorption capacity and photocorrosion still hinder the application of CdS-based nanomaterials in the photocatalytic reaction.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) as an emerging class of crystalline materials with high surface area, tunable composition diversity, and tailorable porosity have attracted enormous attention in solar-driven photocatalytic conversion, which can both ensure the enrichment of reactive substrates and efficient reaction mass transfer and minimize the distance between photosensitizer and reactive sites to dynamically enhance the photocatalytic activity. However, because of the relatively inert feature of the CO2 molecule and difficulties in efficient light-harvesting and product controlling, it is necessary to integrate catalytically active units with MOFs matrix to achieve both reactant/light-harvesting efficiency and photocatalytic activity through the synergistic effect of the guest and MOFs. Zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs), as a famous MOF subclass, have been used as a support to construct a hybrid photocatalyst for enhancing the CO2 conversion by benefiting from their cage channels, excellent stability, and remarkable CO2 capacity. Notably, the formation of heterometallic ZIFs can modulate the band gap structure, gas adsorption, and stability of the framework. However, the heterometallic ZIF-based hybrids for the photocatalytic conversion of CO2 have been rarely reported.
elements.clean_text: Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) as an emerging class of crystalline materials with high surface area, tunable composition diversity, and tailorable porosity have attracted enormous attention in solar-driven photocatalytic conversion, which can both ensure the enrichment of reactive substrates and efficient reaction mass transfer and minimize the distance between photosensitizer and reactive sites to dynamically enhance the photocatalytic activity. However, because of the relatively inert feature of the CO2 molecule and difficulties in efficient light-harvesting and product controlling, it is necessary to integrate catalytically active units with MOFs matrix to achieve both reactant/light-harvesting efficiency and photocatalytic activity through the synergistic effect of the guest and MOFs. Zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs), as a famous MOF subclass, have been used as a support to construct a hybrid photocatalyst for enhancing the CO2 conversion by benefiting from their cage channels, excellent stability, and remarkable CO2 capacity. Notably, the formation of heterometallic ZIFs can modulate the band gap structure, gas adsorption, and stability of the framework. However, the heterometallic ZIF-based hybrids for the photocatalytic conversion of CO2 have been rarely reported.

elements.content: Herein, we designed a “double-synergic effect” for visible light harvesting and CO2/H2O conversion by combining the hybrid shell of bimetallic MOF, Zn/Co-ZIF, with the hybrid photoactive center of Ni-doped CdS nanoparticles (Ni@CdS) to construct a new photocatalysis system Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIF. The uniform dispersion of Ni metal sites on the surface of CdS nanoparticles by the K sp-diversity method efficiently enhanced the light-harvesting ability of Ni@CdS. The hybrid bimetallic Zn/Co-ZIF shell coated on Ni@CdS not only facilitated mass and charge transfer but also had a cocatalyst effect in CO2 activation and conversion through the Co metal nodes of the framework, as illustrated by theoretical calculations. The Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIF photocatalysis system exhibited an unprecedented “2 + 2” ((Zn2+ + Co2+) + (Ni2+ + Cd2+)) double-synergistic effect, leading to one of the highest photocatalytic syngas production rates with excellent recyclability requiring no acetonitrile or noble metal. The H2/CO molar ratio of syngas could be precisely controlled by the ratio of Zn/Co in the bimetallic Zn/Co-ZIF shell.

elements.content: The Ni@CdS nanoparticles were prepared via a reported method with modifications. Typically, 319.8 mg of Cd­(CH3COO)2·2H2O, 99.5 mg of Ni­(CH3COO)2·4H2O, 609 mg of thiourea, and 16 mg of poly­(vinylpyrrolidone) were dissolved in 20 mL of deionized H2O. And then, the solution was kept at 140 °C for different reaction times. The samples were denoted as Ni@CdS-n, where n denotes the hydrothermal time as 2.5, 3.5, 4.5, and 5.5 h, respectively. After being cooled to room temperature, the as-synthesized nanoparticles were recovered by centrifugation, washed with water and ethanol several times, and dried at 60 °C overnight. CdS nanoparticles were synthesized with the same procedure in 3.5 h without adding Ni­(CH3COO)2·4H2O.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis of Ni@CdS Nanoparticles

The Ni@CdS nanoparticles were prepared via a reported method with modifications. Typically, 319.8 mg of Cd(CH3COO)2⋅2H2O, 99.5 mg of Ni(CH3COO)2⋅4H2O, 609 mg of thiourea, and 16 mg of poly(vinylpyrrolidone) were dissolved in 20 mL of deionized H2O. And then, the solution was kept at 140 °C for different reaction times. The samples were denoted as Ni@CdS-n, where n denotes the hydrothermal time as 2.5, 3.5, 4.5, and 5.5 h, respectively. After being cooled to room temperature, the as-synthesized nanoparticles were recovered by centrifugation, washed with water and ethanol several times, and dried at 60 °C overnight. CdS nanoparticles were synthesized with the same procedure in 3.5 h without adding Ni(CH3COO)2⋅4H2O.

elements.content: In general, 6 mg of Ni@CdS nanoparticles was dispersed in 10 mL of methanol with 500.0 mg of 2-methylimidazole and ultrasonicated for 15 min until the solution became homogeneous. Then, 10 mL of methanol solution with 2.0 mM Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O and 2.0 mM Co­(NO3)2·6H2O was added and the solution was left undisturbed for 2 h at room temperature. The resultant samples were centrifuged and washed with methanol several times and dried at 60 °C under a vacuum overnight. The obtained hybrid was denoted as Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIF-1:1, where “1:1” represents the molar ratio of Zn2+/Co2+ in the bimetallic MOF precursor. Ni@CdS encapsulated in the bimetallic MOF with different metal ratios was synthesized according to the same procedure keeping the concentration of divalent metal ions at 4.0 mM in 10 mL of methanol solution and adjusting the ratio of Zn2+/Co2+. The as-synthesized hybrids were denoted as Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIF-3:1 and Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIF-1:3. Ni@CdS⊂ZIF-8 was synthesized according to the above method with 49.3 mg of 2-methylimidazole dissolved in 10 mL of methanol and 10 mL of 15.0 mM Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O in methanol, and Ni@CdS⊂ZIF-67 was synthesized using 500.0 mg of 2-methylimidazole and 6.0 mM Co­(NO3)2·6H2O.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIF-x, Ni@CdS⊂ZIF-8, and Ni@CdS⊂ZIF-67

In general, 6 mg of Ni@CdS nanoparticles was dispersed in 10 mL of methanol with 500.0 mg of 2-methylimidazole and ultrasonicated for 15 min until the solution became homogeneous. Then, 10 mL of methanol solution with 2.0 mM Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O and 2.0 mM Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O was added and the solution was left undisturbed for 2 h at room temperature. The resultant samples were centrifuged and washed with methanol several times and dried at 60 °C under a vacuum overnight. The obtained hybrid was denoted as Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIF-1:1, where "1:1" represents the molar ratio of Zn2+/Co2+ in the bimetallic MOF precursor. Ni@CdS encapsulated in the bimetallic MOF with different metal ratios was synthesized according to the same procedure keeping the concentration of divalent metal ions at 4.0 mM in 10 mL of methanol solution and adjusting the ratio of Zn2+/Co2+. The as-synthesized hybrids were denoted as Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIF-3:1 and Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIF-1:3. Ni@CdS⊂ZIF-8 was synthesized according to the above method with 49.3 mg of 2-methylimidazole dissolved in 10 mL of methanol and 10 mL of 15.0 mM Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O in methanol, and Ni@CdS⊂ZIF-67 was synthesized using 500.0 mg of 2-methylimidazole and 6.0 mM Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O.

elements.content: Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were collected on Japan Rigaku Ultima IV equipped with a Cu Kα radiation source (40 kV, 40 mA). Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was carried out with ZEISS MERLIN Compact. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM), high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM), and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) were acquired on FEI Talos F200X G2. The element content of each sample was analyzed by a Spectro Blue inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed by Thermo Scientific ESCALab250xi using monochromated Al Kα radiation (hν = 1486.6 eV) as the excitation source. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) specific surface areas were conducted by nitrogen adsorption–desorption using Quantachrome Automated Surface Area. The CO2 isotherm adsorption was measured at 25 °C using a Quantachrome Autosorb-1 volumetric desorption analyzer. UV–vis absorption diffuse reflectance spectra (UV–vis DRS) were recorded on a Cary 100 UV–vis spectrophotometer using an integrating sphere accessory. The photoluminescence spectra (PL) were recorded by an FLS1000 fluorescence spectrometer with an excitation wavelength of 394 nm.
elements.clean_text:
Characterization

Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were collected on Japan Rigaku Ultima IV equipped with a Cu Kα radiation source (40 kV, 40 mA). Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was carried out with ZEISS MERLIN Compact. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM), high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM), and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) were acquired on FEI Talos F200X G2. The element content of each sample was analyzed by a Spectro Blue inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed by Thermo Scientific ESCALab250xi using monochromated Al Kα radiation (hν = 1486.6 eV) as the excitation source. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) specific surface areas were conducted by nitrogen adsorption-desorption using Quantachrome Automated Surface Area. The CO2 isotherm adsorption was measured at 25 °C using a Quantachrome Autosorb-1 volumetric desorption analyzer. UV-vis absorption diffuse reflectance spectra (UV-vis DRS) were recorded on a Cary 100 UV-vis spectrophotometer using an integrating sphere accessory. The photoluminescence spectra (PL) were recorded by an FLS1000 fluorescence spectrometer with an excitation wavelength of 394 nm.

elements.content: The Mott–Schottky plots (MS) and transient photocurrent measurements were completed with CHI760E using a traditional three-electrode system. Specifically, a platinum plate was used as the counter electrode and an Ag/AgCl electrode was used as the reference electrode. The preparation of the working electrode was as follows: 5.0 mg of the prepared sample was dispersed in the solution of Nafion/ethanol (10 μL/1 mL) and ultrasonicated for 1 h. Then, 80 μL of the mixture was dropped onto an indium tin oxide (ITO) glass substrate with an area of 1.0 cm2. The obtained electrode was dried at 120 °C under a vacuum overnight. The electrolyte was 0.5 M sodium sulfate aqueous solution. A 300 W Xe lamp with a 420 nm cutoff filter was used as the light source.
elements.clean_text:
Photoelectrochemical Measurements

The Mott-Schottky plots (MS) and transient photocurrent measurements were completed with CHI760E using a traditional three-electrode system. Specifically, a platinum plate was used as the counter electrode and an Ag/AgCl electrode was used as the reference electrode. The preparation of the working electrode was as follows: 5.0 mg of the prepared sample was dispersed in the solution of Nafion/ethanol (10 μL/1 mL) and ultrasonicated for 1 h. Then, 80 μL of the mixture was dropped onto an indium tin oxide (ITO) glass substrate with an area of 1.0 cm2. The obtained electrode was dried at 120 °C under a vacuum overnight. The electrolyte was 0.5 M sodium sulfate aqueous solution. A 300 W Xe lamp with a 420 nm cutoff filter was used as the light source.

elements.content: The photocatalytic CO2 reduction reaction was performed in a 125 mL homemade photoreactor, which was irradiated with a 300 W Xe lamp (HSX-F300, Beijing NBET Technology Co., Ltd.) equipped with a 420 nm cutoff filter at 25 °C. Five milligrams of photocatalyst, 2 mg of CoCl2·6H2O, and 65 mg of 2,2′-bipyridine (bpy) were added into a solution containing 12 mL of deionized H2O and 2 mL of TEOA, and the mixture was ultrasonicated for 15 min. The reactor was filled with 0.1 MPa of high-purity CO2. The gas products were quantitatively analyzed by Agilent 8860 gas chromatography equipped with two thermal conductivity detectors (TCD). Helium was used as the carrier gas to detect H2, and nitrogen was the carrier gas used to detect other gas products.
elements.clean_text:
Photocatalytic Activity Test

The photocatalytic CO2 reduction reaction was performed in a 125 mL homemade photoreactor, which was irradiated with a 300 W Xe lamp (HSX-F300, Beijing NBET Technology Co., Ltd.) equipped with a 420 nm cutoff filter at 25 °C. Five milligrams of photocatalyst, 2 mg of CoCl2⋅6H2O, and 65 mg of 2,2'-bipyridine (bpy) were added into a solution containing 12 mL of deionized H2O and 2 mL of TEOA, and the mixture was ultrasonicated for 15 min. The reactor was filled with 0.1 MPa of high-purity CO2. The gas products were quantitatively analyzed by Agilent 8860 gas chromatography equipped with two thermal conductivity detectors (TCD). Helium was used as the carrier gas to detect H2, and nitrogen was the carrier gas used to detect other gas products.

elements.content: The DFT calculations were carried out on Gaussian 16 program with the B3LYP functional. The geometry optimization was performed using the 6-31++G­(d,p) basis set for the C–H–N–O atoms and LANL2DZ as a pseudopotential and basis set for Co. The elementary steps on the possible active sites were + * CO 2 → CO 2 * CO 2 * + [ H + + e − ] → COOH * COOH * + [ H + + e − ] → CO * + H 2 O CO * → + * CO where * represents the possible active site.
elements.clean_text:
DFT Calculations

The DFT calculations were carried out on Gaussian 16 program with the B3LYP functional. The geometry optimization was performed using the 6-31++G(d,p) basis set for the C-H-N-O atoms and LANL2DZ as a pseudopotential and basis set for Co. The elementary steps on the possible active sites were       +     *     CO   2   →     CO   2       *      1   2        CO   2       *   +  [   H   +   +   e   -   ]  →   COOH     *       3      COOH     *   +  [   H   +   +   e   -   ]  →   CO     *   +   H   2   O     4      CO     *   →   +     *   CO   where * represents the possible active site.

elements.content: The synthesis procedure of the Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIF core–shell structure is illustrated in . First, Ni@CdS nanoparticles as a heterogeneous photosensitizer were prepared by a one-pot hydrothermal method. Owing to the much lower K sp of CdS (10–27) than that of NiS (10–19), pure CdS should preferentially precipitate and grow into nanoparticles at the beginning of the reaction. As the reaction proceeded, the concentration of Cd2+ in the solution gradually decreased, and the reaction of Ni2+ and S2– dominated accordingly. Finally, a Ni-doped CdS shell was deposited on the surface of the as-formed pure CdS nanoparticles, and the amount of Ni doping could be controlled by the reaction time. After that, the bimetallic Zn/Co-ZIF was covered on the surface of the Ni@CdS core through a self-assembly process with the presence of both Zn2+ and Co2+ ions. Furthermore, the metal ratio of the Zn/Co-ZIF shell could be regulated by adjusting the Zn2+/Co2+ molar ratios in the precursor.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structural Characterization

The synthesis procedure of the Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIF core-shell structure is illustrated in . First, Ni@CdS nanoparticles as a heterogeneous photosensitizer were prepared by a one-pot hydrothermal method. Owing to the much lower K sp of CdS (10-27) than that of NiS (10-19), pure CdS should preferentially precipitate and grow into nanoparticles at the beginning of the reaction. As the reaction proceeded, the concentration of Cd2+ in the solution gradually decreased, and the reaction of Ni2+ and S2- dominated accordingly. Finally, a Ni-doped CdS shell was deposited on the surface of the as-formed pure CdS nanoparticles, and the amount of Ni doping could be controlled by the reaction time. After that, the bimetallic Zn/Co-ZIF was covered on the surface of the Ni@CdS core through a self-assembly process with the presence of both Zn2+ and Co2+ ions. Furthermore, the metal ratio of the Zn/Co-ZIF shell could be regulated by adjusting the Zn2+/Co2+ molar ratios in the precursor.

elements.clean_text: 1  Illustration of the Construction of the Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIF Core-Shell System

elements.content: To reveal the feasibility of controlling the amount of Ni doping on the CdS nanoparticles by adjusting the reaction time, XRD was employed to monitor the reaction process. As shown in a, the diffraction patterns of all Ni@CdS nanoparticles exhibit characteristic peaks of hexagonal CdS (PDF#41-1049), which are the same as those of pure CdS nanoparticles obtained from the hydrothermal process. Additionally, the peak at ca. 43.7° slightly shifted toward a higher angle (b), which suggested the successful doping of Ni2+ ions into the lattice of CdS. Furthermore, the chemical composition and the oxidation states of the Ni@CdS hybrids were confirmed by XPS (c). As shown in c, the Ni 2p XPS spectra of Ni@CdS-3.5 showed two peaks of 855.9 and 873.2 eV that were attributed to Ni2+ 2p3/2 and Ni2+ 2p1/2 and two satellite peaks of 860.6 and 878.9 eV, respectively, which was in accordance with the XRD results that confirmed the doping of Ni2+ in the CdS lattice. Furthermore, in the Ni 2p XPS spectra of Ni@CdS-5.5, two new peaks located at 852.9 and 870.1 eV could be assigned to the generation of Ni2+ in NiS due to the prolonged hydrothermal reaction time. The loading content of Ni on the surface of Ni@CdS-n was given by ICP-OES (Table S1), indicating the feasible control of the Ni content in the Ni@CdS hybrid nanoparticles by adjusting time. After the fabrication of the Zn/Co-ZIF shell, XRD patterns of Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIF hybrids exhibited a new group of peaks present in the range of 5–20° (e), which well matched the simulated pattern of ZIF-8, indicating the successful cover of bimetallic Zn/Co-ZIF with ZIF-8-like structures on Ni@CdS nanoparticles through the self-assembly process.

elements.content: The morphologies of the as-prepared Ni@CdS nanoparticles were investigated by SEM and TEM. As shown in d,e, Ni@CdS-3.5 nanoparticles show a raspberry-like shape with an average size of 260 nm, which is similar to the pure CdS nanoparticles fabricated by the same progress without Ni sources (Figure S1a). The lattice spacing of the (002) facets of Ni@CdS-3.5 was 0.315 nm (f), which was slightly narrower than the lattice spacing of the (002) facets of the hexagonal CdS (0.333 nm), further confirming the fabrication of Ni-doped CdS nanoparticles. In addition, adjusting the reaction time of the hydrothermal process slightly influenced the particle size of Ni@CdS nanoparticles (Figure S1b–d). Even if the reaction time was prolonged to 5.5 h, no obvious NiS nanoparticles were observed on the surface of Ni@CdS-5.5 (Figure S2b). The HAADF-STEM image and EDX mapping images confirmed the presence of Cd, Ni, and S elements in the composition of Ni@CdS-3.5 nanoparticles (g). Importantly, the elemental line scanning profiles further showed that the Ni element was mainly distributed on the surface of the Ni@CdS-3.5 nanoparticles (h).
elements.clean_text: The morphologies of the as-prepared Ni@CdS nanoparticles were investigated by SEM and TEM. As shown in d,e, Ni@CdS-3.5 nanoparticles show a raspberry-like shape with an average size of 260 nm, which is similar to the pure CdS nanoparticles fabricated by the same progress without Ni sources (Figure S1a). The lattice spacing of the (002) facets of Ni@CdS-3.5 was 0.315 nm (f), which was slightly narrower than the lattice spacing of the (002) facets of the hexagonal CdS (0.333 nm), further confirming the fabrication of Ni-doped CdS nanoparticles. In addition, adjusting the reaction time of the hydrothermal process slightly influenced the particle size of Ni@CdS nanoparticles (Figure S1b-d). Even if the reaction time was prolonged to 5.5 h, no obvious NiS nanoparticles were observed on the surface of Ni@CdS-5.5 (Figure S2b). The HAADF-STEM image and EDX mapping images confirmed the presence of Cd, Ni, and S elements in the composition of Ni@CdS-3.5 nanoparticles (g). Importantly, the elemental line scanning profiles further showed that the Ni element was mainly distributed on the surface of the Ni@CdS-3.5 nanoparticles (h).

elements.content: The fabrication of Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIF-1:3 with a uniform core–shell structure is verified by the SEM and TEM images in a,b. The Ni@CdS core with the original size and morphology was encapsulated by the Zn/Co-ZIF shell with a thickness of about 70 nm (c and S7). The elemental distribution of the as-synthesized hybrid was also revealed by EDX mapping images (d), demonstrating the uniform composition of both Zn and Co elements in the MOF shell. Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIF core–shell structures with different Zn/Co molar ratios were prepared by the same method. TEM images and elemental mapping images showed that the different Zn/Co molar ratios might influence the thickness of the Zn/Co-ZIF shell (Figures S3–S7), which was due to the different crystallization kinetics of different metal ions with the 2-methylimidazole ligand.

elements.content: N2 adsorption/desorption was applied to characterize the porous structure of the hybrid catalyst Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIF. As shown in f and S8, the BET specific surface areas of Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIF composites are 551.2, 565.6, and 126.5 m2·g–1 with the Zn/Co ratio of 1:3, 1:1, and 3:1, respectively. Moreover, a promising CO2 uptake capacity of Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIF was obtained at 25 °C (g). Furthermore, UV–vis absorption diffuse reflectance spectra (UV–vis DRS) were employed to explore the light-harvesting capacities of all of the samples. For Ni@CdS as a heterogeneous photosensitizer, Ni doping on the CdS nanoparticles broadened the visible-light response range and improved the light-harvesting ability of the hybrids (a). After the fabrication of the Zn/Co-ZIF shell on the Ni@CdS core, the light-harvesting abilities of the photocatalysts were further enhanced (b). Notably, adjusting the Zn/Co metal ratio in the matrix of the bimetallic MOF customized the light absorption capacity in the range of 550–650 nm, which benefitted from the characteristic visible-light absorption of ZIF-67-like structures. These results confirmed that both the doping of Ni on the CdS and the fabrication of the bimetallic MOF shell on the Ni@CdS core contributed to the synergistic improvement of the light-harvesting performance of the double-hybrid photocatalysts.

elements.content: The influence of Ni doping on the photocatalytic reduction of CO2 was evaluated first under visible light. As shown in c and Table S2, doping Ni on the surface of CdS nanoparticles improves the photocatalytic activity notably compared with that of pure CdS. Ni@CdS-3.5 exhibited the highest CO yield rate of 294.1 μmol·h–1·g–1 among all of the tested Ni@CdS nanoparticles with a moderate H2 yield rate of 1835.6 μmol·h–1·g–1, which was 18.2- and 9.2-fold higher than those of the pure CdS nanoparticles, respectively. Although prolonging the hydrothermal time could increase the content of Ni doping in Ni@CdS, Ni@CdS-5.5 did not show better selectivity for CO2 reduction (CO2RR) or higher CO yield rate than others because the formation of NiS on the surface of Ni@CdS-5.5 (c) promoted the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and simultaneously inhibited CO2RR. The results of the further control experiment shown in Figure S10 indicate that the Ni2+ metal sites in Ni@CdS mainly contribute to the hydrogen evolution reaction and thus influence the H2/CO ratio in the product via adjusting the content of Ni. Considering that Ni@CdS-3.5 exhibited highly efficient photogenerated electron transfer and superior catalytic activity in the thermodynamically and kinetically disadvantaged CO2 reduction reaction, it was chosen as the optimal sample to construct the hybrid photocatalyst. The performance of the double-hybrid Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIF in photocatalytic syngas production was evaluated under the same conditions. As shown in d and Table S4, all of the Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIF-x photocatalysts exhibit a significantly enhanced photocatalytic performance compared with that of Ni@CdS-3.5. The optimized production obtained on Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIF-1:3 with a CO yield rate of 948.5 μmol·h–1·g–1 of and an H2 yield rate of 2070.8 μmol·h–1·g–1. The ratio of H2/CO in syngas could be precisely adjusted from 2.2 to 2.8 with the Zn/Co ratio ranging from 1:3 to 3:1, which was hardly achieved by only Ni@CdS nanoparticles without the MOF shell. The Zn/Co-ZIF shell could automatically capture the CO2 molecules and the electronic sacrificial agents and increase their concentrations in the interface between the MOF shell and the Ni@CdS photosensitizer; furthermore, the abundant porosity of the double-hybrid photocatalyst ensured the efficient transportation of gas products.

Photocatalytic Performance

The influence of Ni doping on the photocatalytic reduction of CO2 was evaluated first under visible light. As shown in c and Table S2, doping Ni on the surface of CdS nanoparticles improves the photocatalytic activity notably compared with that of pure CdS. Ni@CdS-3.5 exhibited the highest CO yield rate of 294.1 μmol⋅h-1⋅g-1 among all of the tested Ni@CdS nanoparticles with a moderate H2 yield rate of 1835.6 μmol⋅h-1⋅g-1, which was 18.2- and 9.2-fold higher than those of the pure CdS nanoparticles, respectively. Although prolonging the hydrothermal time could increase the content of Ni doping in Ni@CdS, Ni@CdS-5.5 did not show better selectivity for CO2 reduction (CO2RR) or higher CO yield rate than others because the formation of NiS on the surface of Ni@CdS-5.5 (c) promoted the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and simultaneously inhibited CO2RR. The results of the further control experiment shown in Figure S10 indicate that the Ni2+ metal sites in Ni@CdS mainly contribute to the hydrogen evolution reaction and thus influence the H2/CO ratio in the product via adjusting the content of Ni. Considering that Ni@CdS-3.5 exhibited highly efficient photogenerated electron transfer and superior catalytic activity in the thermodynamically and kinetically disadvantaged CO2 reduction reaction, it was chosen as the optimal sample to construct the hybrid photocatalyst. The performance of the double-hybrid Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIF in photocatalytic syngas production was evaluated under the same conditions. As shown in d and Table S4, all of the Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIF-x photocatalysts exhibit a significantly enhanced photocatalytic performance compared with that of Ni@CdS-3.5. The optimized production obtained on Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIF-1:3 with a CO yield rate of 948.5 μmol⋅h-1⋅g-1 of and an H2 yield rate of 2070.8 μmol⋅h-1⋅g-1. The ratio of H2/CO in syngas could be precisely adjusted from 2.2 to 2.8 with the Zn/Co ratio ranging from 1:3 to 3:1, which was hardly achieved by only Ni@CdS nanoparticles without the MOF shell. The Zn/Co-ZIF shell could automatically capture the CO2 molecules and the electronic sacrificial agents and increase their concentrations in the interface between the MOF shell and the Ni@CdS photosensitizer; furthermore, the abundant porosity of the double-hybrid photocatalyst ensured the efficient transportation of gas products.

elements.content: We further conducted a series of controlled experimental studies on the composite photocatalytic system, as shown in e and Table S4. Either no gas product or only H2 was detected in the reactions proceeded without photocatalyst, light irradiation, TEOA, or CO2, respectively. When using Zn-ZIF or Co-ZIF as the shell only, the resulted hybrid catalysts exhibited much lower activity, indicating the importance of the synergic effect of the bimetallic Zn-Co sites in the bimetallic MOF shell. The recycle stability of Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIF-1:3 was also studied in the photocatalytic CO2/H2O conversion into syngas. After the reaction, the catalyst was recovered by centrifugation, washed with methanol several times, and dried under a vacuum at 60 °C overnight.

elements.content: The catalytic activity of the regenerated double-hybrid photocatalyst showed almost no decay after five cycles, indicating the stable activity during the photocatalytic reaction (f). The XRD pattern and SEM image of recycled photocatalyst also confirmed the stability of Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIF (Figure S12). Furthermore, Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIF-1:3 exhibited higher humidity and chemical stability than Ni@CdS⊂ZIF-67 (Figure S13), which was mainly due to the introduction of Zn2+ ions in the bimetallic MOF shell.

elements.content: Tauc plot was conducted to investigate the band structure of Ni@CdS and Zn/Co-ZIF-1:3 catalytic systems. According to the Tauc plot of Ni@CdS-3.5 converted from the UV–vis DRS spectrum (Figure S14a), the band gap of Ni@CdS-3.5 was determined to be 2.17 eV and that of Zn/Co-ZIF-1:3 was 2.01 eV (Figure S14b). The Mott–Schottky plots calculated the flat-band potential of Ni@CdS-3.5 as −0.88 V (vs NHE), and the positive slopes of the linear parts of the Mott–Schottky plots implied that Ni@CdS-3.5 was an n-type semiconductor (Figure S15a). Generally, the flat-band potential was about 0.1 eV lower than the minimum of the conduction band (CBM) in n-type semiconductors, the whole band structure of the Ni@CdS could thus be figured out with a composition of a CBM at −0.98 V (vs NHE) and a valence band maximum (VBM) at 1.19 V (vs NHE). Similarly, the band structure of Zn/Co-ZIF-1:3 could be revealed as a flat-band potential of −0.82 V (vs NHE) (Figure S15b) with a CBM at −0.92 V (vs NHE) and a VBM at 1.09 V (vs NHE). Accordingly, the photogenerated electrons were transferred from Ni@CdS to Zn/Co-ZIF-1:3 with moderate driving power.

Band Structure Analyses

Tauc plot was conducted to investigate the band structure of Ni@CdS and Zn/Co-ZIF-1:3 catalytic systems. According to the Tauc plot of Ni@CdS-3.5 converted from the UV-vis DRS spectrum (Figure S14a), the band gap of Ni@CdS-3.5 was determined to be 2.17 eV and that of Zn/Co-ZIF-1:3 was 2.01 eV (Figure S14b). The Mott-Schottky plots calculated the flat-band potential of Ni@CdS-3.5 as -0.88 V (vs NHE), and the positive slopes of the linear parts of the Mott-Schottky plots implied that Ni@CdS-3.5 was an n-type semiconductor (Figure S15a). Generally, the flat-band potential was about 0.1 eV lower than the minimum of the conduction band (CBM) in n-type semiconductors, the whole band structure of the Ni@CdS could thus be figured out with a composition of a CBM at -0.98 V (vs NHE) and a valence band maximum (VBM) at 1.19 V (vs NHE). Similarly, the band structure of Zn/Co-ZIF-1:3 could be revealed as a flat-band potential of -0.82 V (vs NHE) (Figure S15b) with a CBM at -0.92 V (vs NHE) and a VBM at 1.09 V (vs NHE). elements.content: To explain the excellent activity of the composite photocatalyst in detail, the separation and transport efficiency of photogenerated electrons and holes in Ni@CdS and Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIF, which are closely correlated to the photocatalytic activity of the hybrid catalysts, have been further studied with steady-state and transient photoluminescence (PL) spectra. As shown in a, an emission wavelength of around 535 nm with the excitation wavelength of 394 nm is observed for all of the tested samples, among which Ni@CdS exhibits the strongest PL emission, indicating that the construction of the core–shell structure of Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIFs readily suppresses the recombination of the photogenerated electron–hole pairs due to the highly efficient charge separation of the double-hybrid system. Furthermore, the transient PL decay spectra (b and S16) and the fitting results (Table S6) show that the average lifetime of Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIF-1:3 (τavg= 8.80 ns) is efficiently prolonged in comparison to that of Ni@CdS (τavg= 6.06 ns) owing to the precise manufacturing of the core–shell structure and the synergistic effect between the two hybrid compositions significantly improve the efficiency of photogenerated charge-carrier separation. The transient photocurrent response of Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIF further illustrates the function of bimetallic Zn/Co-ZIF in promoting electron transfer from Ni@CdS to the reaction active sites in the photocatalytic system under visible-light irradiation (c). The sharp peak appears at the beginning of lighting due to the transient accumulation and rapid recombination of photoinduced charges. It is worthy to note that adding bpy to the reaction system significantly improves the photocurrent response, which well agrees with the catalytic survey results (e) and should be attributed to the electron mediators formed by the coordination of bpy on the Co sites in the bimetallic Zn/Co-ZIF shell.

elements.content: Notably, according to the above experimental results shown in e, Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIF-1:3 with bpy also exhibited a moderate H2 yield rate of 1731.4 μmol·h–1·g–1 and the CO yield rate of 307.9 μmol·h–1·g–1 provided a higher CO yield than that of Ni@CdS-3.5 under normal conditions, which indicated that the additional bpy molecules coordinated with the Co2+ unsaturated sites in Zn/Co-ZIF to provide the active sites for CO2 conversion into CO. The proposition was further verified by a series of control recovery catalytic experiments with Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIF-1:3 as a typical sample (Figure S11). Furthermore, DFT calculations were also performed to further reveal the mechanism of the photocatalytic CO2 reduction reaction. As surveyed by DFT calculations, the unit of Co2+ coordinated by two 2-methylimidazole molecules and one bpy was used to simulate the intermediate catalytic active sites on the surface of the MOF, which was compared with the commonly used [Co­(bpy)3]2+ molecular catalyst (d). CO2 molecule first accepted one electron and one proton to *COOH, and the Gibbs free energy of both catalytic systems was increased, which should be regarded as the rate-determining step. The bpy coordinated MOF site showed a markedly lower energy barrier of 1.37 eV for CO2 hydrogenation to *COOH than that of [Co­(bpy)3]2+ (1.52 eV), suggesting that the MOF shell promoted the activation of CO2 and the formation of crucial intermediate *COOH. In the next step, COOH* to CO* was favorable because this process was a typical ΔG downhill reaction. In particular, the very negative ΔG (−0.93 eV) on the hybrid MOF-bpy unit indicated that the formation and stabilization of CO* species were highly encouraged compared to those of [Co­(bpy)3]2+ without the MOF support. Due to the steep uphill in ΔG of the subsequent conversion to *CHO, the reaction tended to proceed along the relatively low ΔG pathway to produce CO. In a word, the MOF shell covering on Ni@CdS significantly reduced the energy barriers for the catalytic process, facilitated the formation of key intermediate *COOH, and promoted the subsequent conversion of *COOH to *CO.

elements.content: Based on the experimental results and DFT calculations, a mechanism for photocatalytic CO2 reduction to syngas by Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIF is proposed and depicted in e and S13. Before the initiation of the reaction, the CO2 dissolved in H2O and the free bpy and TEOA were enriched in the pores of the Zn/Co-ZIF shell in the hybrid catalyst. Subsequently, as shown in Figure S13, the bpy coordinated with the Co2+ unsaturated metal sites in the Zn/Co-ZIF shell to form the catalytically active units [CoII(bpy)2(MeIM)2]2+ (MeIM = 2-methylimidazole). Under visible light, the reaction was initiated with the reduction of CoII to CoI in [CoII(bpy)2(MeIM)2]2+, which accepted the first photogenerated electron from the excited photosensitizer Ni@CdS. After a bpy molecule was dissociated, the CoI metal center coordinated with a CO2 molecule through an electrophilic attack to further generate CoII–CO2. Then, CoII–CO2 accepted one proton to generate CoII–COOH and then continued to accept another proton for the dehydroxylation process to generate CoIII–CO and a H2O molecule. Finally, the CO dissociated and the CoIII metal center accepted the second photogenerated electron back to its initial state. During the conversion of CO2 into CO, the protons in the system also accepted photogenerated electrons and were reduced to H2, while the photogenerated holes were quenched by TEOA as the electron sacrificial donor.

Subsequently, as shown in Figure S13, the bpy coordinated with the Co2+ unsaturated metal sites in the Zn/Co-ZIF shell to form the catalytically active units [CoII(bpy)2(MeIM)2]2+ (MeIM = 2-methylimidazole). During the conversion of CO2 into CO, the protons in the system also accepted photogenerated electrons and were reduced to H2, while the photogenerated holes were quenched by TEOA as the electron sacrificial donor.

elements.content: In summary, Ni-doped CdS nanoparticles were encapsulated in a bimetallic Zn/Co-ZIF shell to afford a series of double-hybrid photocatalysts, which exhibited an unpresented “2 + 2” synergic interactions and featured one of the highest photocatalytic syngas production rate and excellent recyclability. As the heterogeneous photosensitizer, the controllable Ni doping content on Ni@CdS nanoparticles enhanced the light-harvesting ability and the efficiency of solar energy utilization. The construction of the bimetallic Zn/Co-ZIF shell coating on the hybrid Ni@CdS nanoparticles not only facilitated the CO2 adsorption-activation process but also promoted photogenerated charge-carrier separation and transfer. The composition of the photocatalytic products is switchable by regulating the Zn/Co ratio of the bimetallic Zn/Co-ZIF shell. The design and application of the novel double-hybrid photosensitizer bimetallic MOF “2 + 2” synergy system provided a new avenue for both CO2 recycling and solar energy conversion/storage.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, Ni-doped CdS nanoparticles were encapsulated in a bimetallic Zn/Co-ZIF shell to afford a series of double-hybrid photocatalysts, which exhibited an unpresented "2 + 2" synergic interactions and featured one of the highest photocatalytic syngas production rate and excellent recyclability. As the heterogeneous photosensitizer, the controllable Ni doping content on Ni@CdS nanoparticles enhanced the light-harvesting ability and the efficiency of solar energy utilization. The construction of the bimetallic Zn/Co-ZIF shell coating on the hybrid Ni@CdS nanoparticles not only facilitated the CO2 adsorption-activation process but also promoted photogenerated charge-carrier separation and transfer. The composition of the photocatalytic products is switchable by regulating the Zn/Co ratio of the bimetallic Zn/Co-ZIF shell. The design and application of the novel double-hybrid photosensitizer bimetallic MOF "2 + 2" synergy system provided a new avenue for both CO2 recycling and solar energy conversion/storage.

cln_elements.content: In general, 6 mg of Ni@CdS nanoparticles was dispersed in 10 mL of methanol with 500.0 mg of 2-methylimidazole and ultrasonicated for 15 min until the solution became homogeneous. Then, 10 mL of methanol solution with 2.0 mM Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O and 2.0 mM Co­(NO3)2·6H2O was added and the solution was left undisturbed for 2 h at room temperature. The resultant samples were centrifuged and washed with methanol several times and dried at 60 °C under a vacuum overnight. The obtained hybrid was denoted as Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIF-1:1, where “1:1” represents the molar ratio of Zn2+/Co2+ in the bimetallic MOF precursor. Ni@CdS encapsulated in the bimetallic MOF with different metal ratios was synthesized according to the same procedure keeping the concentration of divalent metal ions at 4.0 mM in 10 mL of methanol solution and adjusting the ratio of Zn2+/Co2+. The as-synthesized hybrids were denoted as Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIF-3:1 and Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIF-1:3. Ni@CdS⊂ZIF-8 was synthesized according to the above method with 49.3 mg of 2-methylimidazole dissolved in 10 mL of methanol and 10 mL of 15.0 mM Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O in methanol, and Ni@CdS⊂ZIF-67 was synthesized using 500.0 mg of 2-methylimidazole and 6.0 mM Co­(NO3)2·6H2O.

Synthesis of Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIF-x, Ni@CdS⊂ZIF-8, and Ni@CdS⊂ZIF-67

In general, 6 mg of Ni@CdS nanoparticles was dispersed in 10 mL of methanol with 500.0 mg of 2-methylimidazole and ultrasonicated for 15 min until the solution became homogeneous. Then, 10 mL of methanol solution with 2.0 mM Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O and 2.0 mM Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O was added and the solution was left undisturbed for 2 h at room temperature. The resultant samples were centrifuged and washed with methanol several times and dried at 60 °C under a vacuum overnight. The obtained hybrid was denoted as Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIF-1:1, where "1:1" represents the molar ratio of Zn2+/Co2+ in the bimetallic MOF precursor. Ni@CdS encapsulated in the bimetallic MOF with different metal ratios was synthesized according to the same procedure keeping the concentration of divalent metal ions at 4.0 mM in 10 mL of methanol solution and adjusting the ratio of Zn2+/Co2+. The as-synthesized hybrids were denoted as Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIF-3:1 and Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIF-1:3. Ni@CdS⊂ZIF-8 was synthesized according to the above method with 49.3 mg of 2-methylimidazole dissolved in 10 mL of methanol and 10 mL of 15.0 mM Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O in methanol, and Ni@CdS⊂ZIF-67 was synthesized using 500.0 mg of 2-methylimidazole and 6.0 mM Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O.

cln_elements.content:
N2 adsorption/desorption was applied to characterize the porous structure of the hybrid catalyst Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIF. As shown in f and S8, the BET specific surface areas of Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIF composites are 551.2, 565.6, and 126.5 m2·g–1 with the Zn/Co ratio of 1:3, 1:1, and 3:1, respectively. Moreover, a promising CO2 uptake capacity of Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIF was obtained at 25 °C (g). Furthermore, UV–vis absorption diffuse reflectance spectra (UV–vis DRS) were employed to explore the light-harvesting capacities of all of the samples. For Ni@CdS as a heterogeneous photosensitizer, Ni doping on the CdS nanoparticles broadened the visible-light response range and improved the light-harvesting ability of the hybrids (a). After the fabrication of the Zn/Co-ZIF shell on the Ni@CdS core, the light-harvesting abilities of the photocatalysts were further enhanced (b). Notably, adjusting the Zn/Co metal ratio in the matrix of the bimetallic MOF customized the light absorption capacity in the range of 550–650 nm, which benefitted from the characteristic visible-light absorption of ZIF-67-like structures. These results confirmed that both the doping of Ni on the CdS and the fabrication of the bimetallic MOF shell on the Ni@CdS core contributed to the synergistic improvement of the light-harvesting performance of the double-hybrid photocatalysts.

Photocatalytic Performance

The influence of Ni doping on the photocatalytic reduction of CO2 was evaluated first under visible light. As shown in c and Table S2, doping Ni on the surface of CdS nanoparticles improves the photocatalytic activity notably compared with that of pure CdS. Ni@CdS-3.5 exhibited the highest CO yield rate of 294.1 μmol·h–1·g–1 among all of the tested Ni@CdS nanoparticles with a moderate H2 yield rate of 1835.6 μmol·h–1·g–1, which was 18.2- and 9.2-fold higher than those of the pure CdS nanoparticles, respectively. Although prolonging the hydrothermal time could increase the content of Ni doping in Ni@CdS, Ni@CdS-5.5 did not show better selectivity for CO2 reduction (CO2RR) or higher CO yield rate than others because the formation of NiS on the surface of Ni@CdS-5.5 (c) promoted the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and simultaneously inhibited CO2RR. The results of the further control experiment shown in Figure S10 indicate that the Ni2+ metal sites in Ni@CdS mainly contribute to the hydrogen evolution reaction and thus influence the H2/CO ratio in the product via adjusting the content of Ni. Considering that Ni@CdS-3.5 exhibited highly efficient photogenerated electron transfer and superior catalytic activity in the thermodynamically and kinetically disadvantaged CO2 reduction reaction, it was chosen as the optimal sample to construct the hybrid photocatalyst. The performance of the double-hybrid Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIF in photocatalytic syngas production was evaluated under the same conditions. As shown in d and Table S4, all of the Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIF-x photocatalysts exhibit a significantly enhanced photocatalytic performance compared with that of Ni@CdS-3.5. The optimized production obtained on Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIF-1:3 with a CO yield rate of 948.5 μmol·h–1·g–1 of and an H2 yield rate of 2070.8 μmol·h–1·g–1. The ratio of H2/CO in syngas could be precisely adjusted from 2.2 to 2.8 with the Zn/Co ratio ranging from 1:3 to 3:1, which was hardly achieved by only Ni@CdS nanoparticles without the MOF shell. The Zn/Co-ZIF shell could automatically capture the CO2 molecules and the electronic sacrificial agents and increase their concentrations in the interface between the MOF shell and the Ni@CdS photosensitizer; furthermore, the abundant porosity of the double-hybrid photocatalyst ensured the efficient transportation of gas products.

Band Structure Analyses

Tauc plot was conducted to investigate the band structure of Ni@CdS and Zn/Co-ZIF-1:3 catalytic systems. According to the Tauc plot of Ni@CdS-3.5 converted from the UV–vis DRS spectrum (Figure S14a), the band gap of Ni@CdS-3.5 was determined to be 2.17 eV and that of Zn/Co-ZIF-1:3 was 2.01 eV (Figure S14b). The Mott–Schottky plots calculated the flat-band potential of Ni@CdS-3.5 as −0.88 V (vs NHE), and the positive slopes of the linear parts of the Mott–Schottky plots implied that Ni@CdS-3.5 was an n-type semiconductor (Figure S15a). Generally, the flat-band potential was about 0.1 eV lower than the minimum of the conduction band (CBM) in n-type semiconductors, the whole band structure of the Ni@CdS could thus be figured out with a composition of a CBM at −0.98 V (vs NHE) and a valence band maximum (VBM) at 1.19 V (vs NHE). Similarly, the band structure of Zn/Co-ZIF-1:3 could be revealed as a flat-band potential of −0.82 V (vs NHE) (Figure S15b) with a CBM at −0.92 V (vs NHE) and a VBM at 1.09 V (vs NHE). Accordingly, the photogenerated electrons were transferred from Ni@CdS to Zn/Co-ZIF-1:3 with moderate driving power.

Charge Dynamics and Mechanism Analyses

To explain the excellent activity of the composite photocatalyst in detail, the separation and transport efficiency of photogenerated electrons and holes in Ni@CdS and Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIF, which are closely correlated to the photocatalytic activity of the hybrid catalysts, have been further studied with steady-state and transient photoluminescence (PL) spectra. As shown in a, an emission wavelength of around 535 nm with the excitation wavelength of 394 nm is observed for all of the tested samples, among which Ni@CdS exhibits the strongest PL emission, indicating that the construction of the core–shell structure of Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIFs readily suppresses the recombination of the photogenerated electron–hole pairs due to the highly efficient charge separation of the double-hybrid system. Furthermore, the transient PL decay spectra (b and S16) and the fitting results (Table S6) show that the average lifetime of Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIF-1:3 (τavg= 8.80 ns) is efficiently prolonged in comparison to that of Ni@CdS (τavg= 6.06 ns) owing to the precise manufacturing of the core–shell structure and the synergistic effect between the two hybrid compositions significantly improve the efficiency of photogenerated charge-carrier separation. The transient photocurrent response of Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIF further illustrates the function of bimetallic Zn/Co-ZIF in promoting electron transfer from Ni@CdS to the reaction active sites in the photocatalytic system under visible-light irradiation (c). The sharp peak appears at the beginning of lighting due to the transient accumulation and rapid recombination of photoinduced charges. It is worthy to note that adding bpy to the reaction system significantly improves the photocurrent response, which well agrees with the catalytic survey results (e) and should be attributed to the electron mediators formed by the coordination of bpy on the Co sites in the bimetallic Zn/Co-ZIF shell.

Notably, according to the above experimental results shown in e, Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIF-1:3 with bpy also exhibited a moderate H2 yield rate of 1731.4 μmol·h–1·g–1 and the CO yield rate of 307.9 μmol·h–1·g–1 provided a higher CO yield than that of Ni@CdS-3.5 under normal conditions, which indicated that the additional bpy molecules coordinated with the Co2+ unsaturated sites in Zn/Co-ZIF to provide the active sites for CO2 conversion into CO. The proposition was further verified by a series of control recovery catalytic experiments with Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIF-1:3 as a typical sample (Figure S11). Furthermore, DFT calculations were also performed to further reveal the mechanism of the photocatalytic CO2 reduction reaction. As surveyed by DFT calculations, the unit of Co2+ coordinated by two 2-methylimidazole molecules and one bpy was used to simulate the intermediate catalytic active sites on the surface of the MOF, which was compared with the commonly used [Co­(bpy)3]2+ molecular catalyst (d). CO2 molecule first accepted one electron and one proton to *COOH, and the Gibbs free energy of both catalytic systems was increased, which should be regarded as the rate-determining step. The bpy coordinated MOF site showed a markedly lower energy barrier of 1.37 eV for CO2 hydrogenation to *COOH than that of [Co­(bpy)3]2+ (1.52 eV), suggesting that the MOF shell promoted the activation of CO2 and the formation of crucial intermediate *COOH. In the next step, COOH* to CO* was favorable because this process was a typical ΔG downhill reaction. In particular, the very negative ΔG (−0.93 eV) on the hybrid MOF-bpy unit indicated that the formation and stabilization of CO* species were highly encouraged compared to those of [Co­(bpy)3]2+ without the MOF support. Due to the steep uphill in ΔG of the subsequent conversion to *CHO, the reaction tended to proceed along the relatively low ΔG pathway to produce CO. In a word, the MOF shell covering on Ni@CdS significantly reduced the energy barriers for the catalytic process, facilitated the formation of key intermediate *COOH, and promoted the subsequent conversion of *COOH to *CO.

cln_elements.content: (a) UV–vis DRS of Ni@CdS-n. (b) UV–vis DRS of Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIF hybrids. (c) Yield rates of H2 and CO on Ni@CdS. (d) Yield rates of H2 and CO on Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIF. (e) Results of controlled experiments. (f) Yield rates of gas products on recycled Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIF-1:3.
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  (a) UV-vis DRS of Ni@CdS-n. (b) UV-vis DRS of Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIF hybrids. (c) Yield rates of H2 and CO on Ni@CdS. (d) Yield rates of H2 and CO on Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIF. (e) Results of controlled experiments. (f) Yield rates of gas products on recycled Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIF-1:3.

cln_elements.content: (a) Steady-state photoluminescence spectra of Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIF hybrids. (b) Transient photoluminescence spectra of Ni@CdS-3.5 and Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIF-1:3. (c) Photocurrent responses of CO2 reduction system with different components under UV–vis illumination (λ > 420 nm). (d) Free energy diagram for the pathways of CO2 conversion to CO on [Co­(bpy)3]2+ (blue) and Zn/Co-ZIF modified by bpy (orange) based on DFT calculations. The inserted figures were the optimized model of adsorbed atoms in various states (O: red, Co: purple, N: blue, C: gray, H: white). (e) Schematic illustrations of the band-level alignment and electron transfer among the Ni@CdS photosensitizer, the Zn/Co-ZIF cocatalyst, and the photocatalytic CO2RR and HER process.
cln_elements.clean_text: 4  (a) Steady-state photoluminescence spectra of Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIF hybrids. (b) Transient photoluminescence spectra of Ni@CdS-3.5 and Ni@CdS⊂Zn/Co-ZIF-1:3. (c) Photocurrent responses of CO2 reduction system with different components under UV-vis illumination (λ > 420 nm). (d) Free energy diagram for the pathways of CO2 conversion to CO on [Co(bpy)3]2+ (blue) and Zn/Co-ZIF modified by bpy (orange) based on DFT calculations. The inserted figures were the optimized model of adsorbed atoms in various states (O: red, Co: purple, N: blue, C: gray, H: white). (e) Schematic illustrations of the band-level alignment and electron transfer among the Ni@CdS photosensitizer, the Zn/Co-ZIF cocatalyst, and the photocatalytic CO2RR and HER process.
